title: College Savings Calculator (529 Plan)

seo.title: College Savings Calculator | 529 Plan Projector
seo.description: Will you have enough for your child's education? Project future tuition costs and see if your current savings plan measures up. Accounts for inflation and investment growth.

summary: College costs are rising faster than inflation. Use this tool to project the future cost of a 4-year degree and see if your 529 plan is on track.

faq.a: As of 2024, the average annual cost (tuition + fees + room/board) is about $24,000 for in-state public universities and $56,000 for private colleges. Ivy League schools can exceed $85,000 per year.
A 529 plan is a tax-advantaged savings account designed for education costs. Money grows tax-free, and withdrawals are tax-free if used for qualified expenses (tuition, books, etc.).

faq.q: What is a realistic tuition inflation rate?
faq.a: Historically, college tuition has risen about 5% to 8% per yearâ€”roughly double the rate of normal inflation. We recommend using at least 5% to be safe.

faq.q: What if I have a funding gap?
faq.a: Don't panic. You have options: increase monthly contributions, look for scholarships, consider community college for the first 2 years, or plan for student loans to cover the difference.

article.heading: The $200,000 Question
article.body:
For many parents, the sticker shock of higher education is terrifying. If a private college costs $60,000 today, and costs rise by 5% annually, a four-year degree for a newborn could cost over **$350,000** in 18 years. 

Waiting until high school to start saving is a mathematical disaster. The earlier you start, the more you can rely on compound interest rather than your own paycheck.

article.heading: The Power of the 529 Plan
article.body:
The 529 Plan is the 401(k) of education. 
*   **Tax-Free Growth:** If you invest $10,000 and it grows to $20,000, you pay zero capital gains tax on that $10,000 profit.
*   **Tax-Free Withdrawals:** As long as the money goes to the school (or books/laptops), the IRS doesn't touch it.
*   **State Tax Deductions:** Many states (like NY, PA, IL) let you deduct contributions from your state income taxes.

article.heading: Variables You Can Control
article.body:
You cannot control tuition inflation or market returns, but you can control:
1.  **Contribution Rate:** Even an extra $50/month makes a huge difference over 18 years.
2.  **School Choice:** Public in-state universities are often half the price of private schools.
3.  **Living Arrangements:** Room and board is often 40-50% of the 'College Cost'. Living at home can slash the funding gap in half.
